message: Are there any Computer Engineering/Communications Engineering majors here? I'd like to know what the difference between the two majors is and which major has more job opportunities. I personally want to work as a Software Engineer, but I have to choose between these two. Thanks in advance!

data.message: Go for computer engineering if you want to do software. Communications is for things like information theory, microwaves, signal processing, etc.
My understanding is that they focus more on hardware. Is that actually the case?

Both are not about software engineering. Both have produced software engineers.

When applying for your first engineering job, computer engineering will be easier if the company cares so much about having a relevant degree.

Computer engineering will be easier to study and have relatively more software related subjects than communication.

So, if you want to be a software engineer. And have to choose between the two, go for computer engineering.

Disclaimer: I'm a computer engineering graduate. We have a few ones in the admins

I am actually Major Computer minor Communication

Communication Engineering to me is kinda dull, some formulas, some stuff to be memorized, a way of problem solving and you're good to go, I never liked it, I even ignored the minor when I was job searching, although some communication Engineering subjects were pretty useful in CS"Information Theory, and DSP" others like Antenna, wave propagation, microwave were completely a waste of my time and effort.

Ok so everyone seems to be in favor of Computer Engineering. One last question, though, what's the job market like for them? I might be surrounded by the wrong people (hopefully), but I always hear that it's bad.

Well good luck finding a communication Engineering job :D, at Alexandria University around 400 students graduate every year.
but in Computer Engineering 80 "computers and systems" "120 computer and communication" 
and in communication engineering finding a decent job is really hard, while in CS you can always get what you deserve based on your experience :)

If you want to be a software engineer, as I said computer engineering will have a very small advantage over communication.

But let me make it clear. It's a good pay relatively comfortable job with low barrier to entry and everyone knows this. 

This means: Of course the job market will have a lot of competition and you will need to do a lot of self study and networking and whatever to get a good opportunity.
